content:
I've removed the tag "Breadth First Search" as it's a duplicate of "BFS" and also this puzzle is the only one that uses the long tag. See also:

https://forum.codingame.com/t/learning-tags-cleanup-normalization/186567

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very fun. Not really easy to work with Graphs and Breadth First Search, but as said in other approvals, the very clear instructions and the fact that you don't need optimization keep it simple. Nice Puzzle!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The statement is clear, there's no problems with test ans it's clearly an easy puzzle as it can be solved without any optimization.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving, see below.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is a perfect way to practice with graphs. That on itself I always find a bit challenging, but it deserves the Easy category because the task is very clear, so it is very clear what you need to code towards. There are no annoying small surprises to turn it into a parsing and debugging challenge (the input is consistent and straightforward) - it keeps the challenge cleanly about graphs.

I am close to approving (nice puzzle!). For some reason I have code that passes all tests & validators except for validator 5. I am a bit at a loss on what to look for; do you happen to know anything that would be special about validator 5 versus all other cases?

EDIT: I found it - at validator 5 there is a comma at the end of your first movie listing (Aishi Roy,). Therefore my python .split turned that name into 'Aishi Roy,'. I think it is not something you meant to put in (I get the impression you meant to make the listing consistent and easy for parsing, with the ':' between title and cast and ',' supposed to separate actors, and no colons or commas in names to mess with the player).

How fun!!

I like your banner image a lot too
I am not enough leveled in puzzle games to approved it but I upvote your solution !

I submitted this as a clash first, but people felt it was too hard so I'm submitting as an Easy puzzle now. Here's the old clash:

https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/79316fbe12b2b6aaae08701c892f6ee98250a?comment=178988

Edit:
In the end, the clash was accepted, so now I've made this puzzle a bit harder to differentiate it.

Changes have been made to the test cases to make it so that multiple paths exist of different length so that BFS is strongly needed.
I've now added a pair of extra hard tests including all the movies I've listed in other rounds, and I've also made the second last pair harder than in the clash.

Thanks so much for spotting that! I must've removed some actor manually and forgotten the comma.

That would have been an annoying bug to make it to the submission, thanks for spotting it. All fixed now.
Thank you. It seems harder to get approvals on puzzles than clashes. I appreciate it!

Absolutely. And the harder the puzzle, the harder to come by approvals. I think I will need a couple of months for my Rummikub contributionsðŸ™ƒ. Makes sense though; I also mainly validate clashes and some easy level puzzles; the higher ones simply take more time..

So true. I just spent 90 minutes on your Rummmikub 1, but only managed to solve the first 6 test/validator pairs so far. I've not written my code in a way that's ideal for solving it when there's more than one step involved though, so will probably take a lot more work if I manage to finish it.

I usually avoid medium/hard puzzles because they really do take some serious time and planning. Will give it another shot when I can.

Hah it was of course my secret intent to draw out an extra approver by namedropping my contributions :-P, thanks for at least starting on it. But for me exactly the same; in the weeks that I suddenly have a community contribution urge again, I validate a lot of clashes, a couple of easy puzzles, but almost never a medium or hard puzzle.

In some way you could say that for a healthy pace of new contributions, every contribution creator should validate at least three other contributions for every one he makes, at the same level of the contribution he created (since the creator also forces three others to check his single contribution).  I think I fail on that target, especially in the puzzles.

Also affects : 'Test 6' and 'Validator 6'

Same movie "The Two Companions"

Didn't cause an error, so I've just spent over an hour manually working that huge solution to find out why my solution says BN=2 and the correct answer is BN=4

I only came here out of desperation after butchering my 'c' code trying to find the problem.

Please fix all occurrences of "The Companions"

: /

Do you mean 'The Two Companions'? And, what is different about the format of that listing versus other movies? 
"The Two Companions: Priyanka Bhattacharjee, Aishi Roy"
I see {movie name}: {actor1}, {actor2}, which is the common format, right?

sorry, yes, The Two Companions

As you say, it had :
{movie name}: {actor1}, {actor2},

It should be :
{movie name}: {actor1}, {actor2}

This movie was the only one in the test data that had a trailing Comma and Space before the EOL.

I see someone has edited it since I posted.

It was exactly the same error that StepBack13 had to fix in Validator 5, but it's all good now : )

Ah ok, weird that my code did not fail on that one earlier. My earlier post was ambiguous, I strictly meant that I saw "{movie name}: {actor1}, {actor2}" - but probably @stepback13 had already fixed it before I checked.

Ah, okay.  Yes, I think someone fixed it quite soon after I posted : )

I think all the test cases and validators are fixed now.

Good puzzle : )

Thanks for pointing this out, PewPewBewm.
 I did indeed fix it after seeing your comment, but hadn't replied yet, because I wanted to fully check that there were no more issues, but then got side-tracked. Sorry for causing you such confusion in the meantime!

No problem Step,

And thanks for a great puzzle.  Had a lot of fun solving it in C  : )
